Graphical abstract The most advanced progress of bimetallic tellurides electrodes from synthesis to application for alkali metal ion batteries (Li-ion, Na-ion, and K-ion), supercapacitor, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is systematically reviewed. The rapid growth in global energy demand has necessitated the development of efficient energy storage and conversion devices, with the aim of enhancing grid stability, promoting the adoption of electric vehicles, and powering portable electronics. However, the performance of these devices is constrained by the limitations of traditional electrode materials and catalysts. Bimetallic tellurides have emerged as a promising solution due to their exceptional synergistic effects, high electronic conductivity, abundant redox-active sites, and outstanding electrochemical stability. Nevertheless, achieving cost-effective synthesis and stable applications remains a significant challenge. Hence, the most recent advances of bimetallic tellurides electrodes from synthesis to application are systematically reviewed. Several synthetic strategies for exquisite bimetallic tellurides nanostructures, including tellurization, ball-milling, solvo/hydrothermal, electrodeposition, wet chemical, and template method, are discussed. Moreover, the applications of bimetallic tellurides are extensively summarized in energy storage and conversion devices, which include alkali metal-ion batteries (Li-ion, Na-ion, and K-ion), supercapacitor, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Besides, the challenges and potential solutions of bimetallic telluride for energy applications are also suggested. This work provides fundamental insight and guidelines for the future design of bimetallic tellurides in energy storage and conversion technologies. Keywords Bimetallic tellurides Synergistic effects Ion batteries Supercapacitors Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Energy storage technologies are essential for the large-scale integration of renewable energy sources and electric transportation systems [1]. In recent years, lithium-ion batteries have been successfully commercialized due to their advantages of high energy density and long lifespan [2]. However, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are becoming increasingly expensive due to the uneven distribution and limited availability of lithium resources [3]. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (PIBs), which share similar characteristics with lithium-ion batteries, are gaining attention [4]. Sodium and potassium are much more abundant than lithium in the Earth's crust and are widely used due to their abundance, low cost, and excellent chemical stability [5]. Although traditional batteries offer relatively high energy density, they still face limitations in terms of high power density and fast charging and discharging [6,7]. Supercapacitors are a novel type of energy storage technology capable of meeting the demands for high power density [8], fast charging and discharging, long lifespan, and sustainable energy integration make supercapacitors superior to traditional batteries and capacitors [9], and are widely used in energy recovery and storage, back-up power supplies, electronic devices, and power quality improvement [10,11]. Additionally, electrocatalysis, as a green energy storage technology, holds significant potential in areas such as energy conversion, environmental protection, and synthetic chemistry [12,13]. Electrocatalytic technology facilitates the water-splitting reaction for hydrogen production [14], enabling efficient energy conversion and playing a crucial role in the development of new energy sources [15]. To accelerate the reaction rate, it is essential to develop electrocatalytic electrode materials with higher activity and stability [16]. Currently, research on transition metal sulfides and selenides is relatively advanced; however, their low conductivity limits carrier transport during electrochemical reactions [17–19]. Mixed metal sulfides and selenides have garnered significant attention as promising electrode materials for ion batteries due to their excellent electrochemical performance, unique molecular structures, and abundant redox reactions [20–22]. Moreover, they exhibit superior electrochemical properties compared to single-metal sulfides and selenides [23]. This suggests that the physical and chemical properties of these materials can be tailored by adjusting the metal ratio or composition, thereby enabling more diverse applications [24]. By rationally designing bimetallic structures, the performance and application potential of these materials can be further enhanced [25]. Tellurium, a member of the same periodic group as sulfur and selenium, possesses strong metallic properties [26] (Fig. 1 ).The tellurides formed with transition metals also exhibit enhanced metallic characteristics [27]. The electrical conductivity of tellurium (10 × 103 S m−1) is much higher than that of sulfur (5 × 10−28 S m−1) and selenium (1 × 10−3 S m−1) [28], positioning it as a promising candidate for advanced electrochemical electrode materials [29]. A comprehensive comparison of bimetallic tellurides, single-metal telluride, sulfide, and selenide counterparts in terms of performance, cost, and scalability is summarized in Table 1 [30–35]. As demonstrated, bimetallic tellurides exhibit superior development prospects. Furthermore, Te has a relatively low electronegativity and a larger atomic size, which can mitigate volume changes during charging and discharging, thereby enhancing structural stability [36–38]. It can provide an outstanding volume capacity and gravimetric capacity [39]. Single-metal and bimetallic tellurides exhibit distinct advantages and disadvantages, as summarized in Fig. 2 (a) [40,41]. Single-metal tellurides offer a high theoretical specific capacity, which enables increased energy density in energy storage devices [42]. They are also relatively low in cost and easy to synthesize [43]. However, single-metal tellurides suffer from poor stability and electrical conductivity [44], and are highly sensitive to air exposure and the charging and discharging cycles [45], and they may also face the problem of slow kinetics in some applications, which can negatively impact reaction rates and performance [46]. In contrast, bimetallic tellurides, compared to their single-metal counterparts, benefit from enhanced electrical conductivity that promotes electron transport, improving charging and discharging efficiency and rate performance [47]. The combination of bimetallic elements has rich redox reactions that can increase the charge storage sites [48], which can significantly increase the specific capacity and energy density of energy storage devices, providing strong support for the development of high-performance energy storage devices [12]. The chemical bond network formed by bimetallic elements and tellurium is more stable, and during the charging and discharging cycles [38], it can effectively resist the deformation and destruction of the structure [49]. This enhanced stability helps reduce material property degradation and extends the material's service life [50]. In recent years, the electrochemical performance of energy storage devices has been significantly enhanced through the design of mixed metal tellurides, which offer abundant charge storage and redox reaction sites [51]. Fig. 2(b) illustrates the number of papers published on single-metal tellurides, which has remained a research hotspot. However, related research primarily focuses on the synthesis methods for tellurium metal, single-metal tellurides, and bimetallic tellurides. Fig. 2(c) shows the publication trends for bimetallic tellurides, indicating that research in this area is still limited. While previous reviews may have covered applications of single metal telluride tellurides, this review comprehensively integrates and analyzes the synthetic strategies, application progress, electrochemical mechanism and challenges of bimetallic tellurides in the field of energy storage and conversion, particularly in alkali metal-ion batteries (LIBs, SIBs and PIBs), supercapacitors, and electrocatalysis (HER and OER) (Fig. 3 ). Owning to the excellent conductivity, electrochemical activity, and catalytic performance, bimetallic tellurides play an important role in enhancing battery energy density, extending cycle life, improving supercapacitor performance, and accelerating electrocatalytic reactions. Therefore, in-depth research on their applications in these areas not only drives innovation in energy technologies but also provides solid technical support for achieving green and low-carbon economic goals. 2 Working mechanism of energy storage and conversion devices 2.1 Alkali metal ion batteries As shown in Fig. 4 , alkali metal-ion batteries primarily consist of anode materials, cathode materials, separators, and organic electrolytes [52]. The positive and negative electrodes are connected side by side and separated by an insulating separator, which is a polymer film with a large number of micropores. It is used to isolate the positive and negative electrodes [53,54], allowing ions to pass freely while electrons cannot [55]. The electrolyte serves as the medium for ion transport within the battery and is typically an organic solvent containing alkali metal salts [56,57]. The cathode materials in LIBs primarily include compounds such as LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, and LiNi x Co y Mn1− x − y O2 [58]. The anode materials are typically graphite or carbon-based materials with a graphite-like structure [59]. The electrolyte generally consists of a carbonate solvent dissolved in LiPF6 [60]. Taking the lithium-ion battery as an example, the cathode is LiCoO2 and the anode is graphite [61]. During the charging process, current passes through the battery, and lithium ions enter the electrolyte from the cathode, move to the anode side through the “passage” of the separator's numerous pores [62], and combine with the electrons that reach the anode side through the external circuit [63,64]. During the discharging process, electrons migrate to the cathode through the external circuit, while lithium ions enter the electrolyte from the anode, then pass through the separator to reach the cathode and combine with the electrons that have already arrived at the cathode side [65,66]. This entire charging and discharging process is reversible, allowing the lithium-ion battery to undergo multiple charge and discharge cycles [67]. Compared to lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion and potassium-ion batteries share a similar structure [68]. The insulating separators in sodium and potassium-ion batteries are primarily made of glass fibers, as the separators used in lithium-ion batteries have poor compatibility with these systems [69]. In sodium-ion batteries, common anode materials include carbon-based materials, organic materials, titanium-based materials, chalcogenide materials, and alloys [70]. Common cathode materials consist of sodium nickel cobalt manganese oxides, sodium nickel cobalt aluminum oxides, sodium manganese oxides, and sodium iron phosphates [71]. The electrolyte typically consists of an organic sodium salt, such as sodium perchlorate (NaClO4) or sodium hexafluorophosphate (NaPF6) dissolved in a carbonate solvent or an ether solvent [72]. Potassium-ion batteries are the third most common alkali metal-ion battery system and operate based on a similar “rocking chair” principle as lithium- and sodium-ion batteries [56,73]. The reported cathode materials for potassium-ion batteries mainly include Prussian blue analogues, layered oxides, polyanionic compounds, and organic materials [74]. Depending on the potassium storage mechanism, anode materials include intercalation-type carbon-based materials, alloy-type anode materials, and conversion-type anode materials [75–77]. The electrolytes are typically potassium salt solutions, organic solvent electrolytes, or polymer gel electrolytes [78]. 2.2 Supercapacitors As shown in Fig. 5 , supercapacitors consist of five main components: electrodes, electrolytes, current collectors, separators, and packaging materials [79]. The two conductors of the capacitor are typically metal plates or films, with the electrode material playing a critical role in the capacitor's performance [80]. In recent years, various materials have been explored as electrode materials for supercapacitors, including carbon-based materials, conductive polymers, molybdenum sulfide, black phosphorus, metal oxides, heteroatom-doped carbon materials, metal nitrides, two-dimensional transition metal carbides, as well as metal-organic framework (MOF) materials and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [81–83]. The separators are typically made from materials such as non-woven fabrics, separator papers, or polymer films [84]. When the capacitor is connected to a power source, electrons are pushed onto the positive electrode while electrons on the negative electrode are drawn away [85]. Negative charges accumulate on the positive electrode, and positive charges accumulate on the negative electrode [39]. The movement of electrons between the conductors generates an electric field, leading to charge accumulation. With the capacitor charging, the intensity of the electric field increases [86]. When the capacitor is connected to a load in the circuit, the stored charges begin to flow, discharging the capacitor [87]. The energy stored in the electric field is released, and the electrons flow back to the original conductors [88]. This charging and discharging process is reversible, allowing the capacitor to continuously store and release charges [89]. 2.3 Hydrogen/oxygen evolution reaction As shown in Fig. 6 , water electrolysis consists of the OER at the anode and the HER at the cathode [90]. The OER is a multi-electron transfer process, while the HER involves a two-electron transfer process [91]. The OER exhibits inert kinetic characteristics, and reducing its overpotential by optimizing and designing more efficient catalysts has become a key research goal [92]. Under acidic conditions, the oxides of precious metals such as Ir and Ru serve as the most effective electrocatalysts. In alkaline conditions, transition metal hydroxides demonstrate excellent catalytic activity [93]. RuO2 and IrO2 as classic OER catalysts, which is offer high electrocatalytic activity and stability [94]. However, their high cost and limited global reserves restrict the large-scale production and application of these precious metal oxides [95]. These catalysts are typically bound to the electrode surface with polymer binders, which can block active sites and cause the catalysts to detach from the electrode [96]. The reaction equations for the OER vary depending on the pH of the aqueous solution [97]. The HER is the process by which electrical energy catalyzes the decomposition of water molecules into hydrogen. Typically, catalysts are applied to the electrode surface to facilitate the reaction [98]. Common HER catalysts include platinum-group metals, non-platinum-group transition metals, cobalt-based compounds, nitrides, carbon-based materials, and transition metal sulfides [99,100]. 3 Synthesis and applications of bimetallic tellurides for energy storage and conversion 3.1 Energy storage devices 3.1.1 Lithium-ion battery Researchers Hu et al. [101] synthesized cubic nanostructures composed of copper-doped-induced cobalt telluride nanoparticles (Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs, as shown in Fig. 7 a) using a simple chemical etching and subsequent tellurization process. Fig. 7(b) illustrates the schematic diagram of the copper-doped Co(1− x )Te structure. The magnified regions at the (101), (102), and (110) positions show a shift in diffraction peaks to higher 2θ values, indicating that larger copper atoms have replaced smaller cobalt atoms. Fig. 7(c) demonstrates that, compared with CoTe@NC HNBs, the Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs retain good lithium storage performance even at high current densities of 3 and 5 A g−1. Fig. 7(d) presents the difference in electron charge density between the CoTe@NC HNBs and Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs electrodes. The left side of Fig. 7(d) shows electron depletion and accumulation, indicating that the electron interaction at the CoTe@NC heterointerfaces is limited. After copper introduction, the right side of Fig. 7(d) shows more electron aggregation around the NC on the Cu-Co1− x Te@Nc heterointerfaces, suggesting an improvement in the binding energy between Cu-Co1− x Te and NC, which improves electron transfer. As shown in Fig. 7(e), the hollow nanostructure of the NC framework is more conducive to electron/ion transfer at the electrolyte/electrode interface and introduces more active sites for lithium storage. The co-vacancies reduce the GH* of Cu-Co1− x Te, further improving the kinetic performance of the hybrid electrode structure and thus achieving better rate performance. The strong electron interaction between Cu-Co1− x Te and NC enables the Cu-Co1− x Te nanoparticles to have good adhesion to the NC substrate, promoting charge transfer and realizing high structural stability. Fig. 7(f) depicts the schematic diagram of a full cell with a LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode and Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs anode, demonstrating its potential for full-cell applications. Fig. 7(g) presents the Ragone plot of the LCO//Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs device, revealing the relationship between power density (PD) and energy density (ED) and confirming that the Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs electrode is a promising anode material for lithium-ion batteries. 3.1.2 Sodium ion battery Jiang et al. [102] self-assembled CoZn-ZIFs based on the metal-organic framework, followed by sintering and tellurization to produce CoZn-Te composite petal-like nitrogen-doped carbon (CoZn-Te/NC), as illustrated in Fig. 8 (a). The transmission electron microscope (TEM) image in Fig. 8(b) clearly reveals the characteristic petal-like morphology of CoZn-Te/NC. As shown in Fig. 8(c), the crystal planes of CoTe2(111) and ZnTe (200) correspond to the lattice spacings of 0.28 and 0.30 nm, respectively, confirming the formation of a two-phase structure. When used as the anode in a sodium-ion battery, as shown in the comparison in Fig. 8(d) at a current density of 200 mA g−1, the CoZn-Te/NC anode exhibited a discharge capacity of 371 mAh g−1 in the second cycle and a reversible capacity of 314 mAh g−1 after 170 cycles, equivalent to a capacity retention rate of 89.7%. In contrast, the carbon-nitrogen doped CoTe2 (CoTe2/NC) anode showed a continuous capacity decline and even failed after 88 cycles, demonstrating that CoZn-Te/NC has higher capacity performance. As shown in Fig. 8(e), the rate performance of the CoZn-Te/NC and CoTe2/NC anodes was tested. The specific capacities at current densities of 0.07, 0.1, 0.2, 0.7, 1.0, 2.0, and 7.0 A g−1 were 424, 372, 316, 276, 277, 178, and 171 mAh g−1, respectively. Even at a current density as high as 10 A g−1, a discharge capacity of 106 mAh g−1 could be achieved. When the current density was returned to 0.07 A g−1, the capacity recovered to 382 mAh g−1, indicating that the CoZn-Te/NC anode has excellent rate performance. Furthermore, Fig. 8(f) compares the specific capacitance contribution ratios of CoZn-Te/NC and CoTe2/NC at different scanning rates The CoZn-Te/NC exhibits a higher pseudo-capacitance contribution than the CoTe2/NC anode, suggesting superior Na+ reaction kinetics, which are also responsible for its excellent rate performance. Additionally, Fig. 8(g) shows the results of the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) for the CoZn-Te/NC and CoTe2/NC electrodes. The GITT measurements indicate that CoZn-Te/NC has a higher Na+ diffusion coefficient than CoTe2/NC, suggesting that CoZn-Te/NC possesses a highly active heterogeneous interface with numerous defects, reflecting its superior ion transport and diffusion kinetics. Finally, Fig. 8(h) is the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the first two cycles of CoZn-Te/NC, revealing the electrochemical reaction mechanism of the CoZn-Te/NC anode. When the open-circuit voltage was discharged to 0.01 V, the characteristic peaks of ZnTe and CoTe2 were observed to disappear, and Na2Te and NaZn13 were formed. Upon charging from 0.01 to 3.0 V, the XRD pattern revealed changes in the phases of ZnTe and CoTe2. The structural stability mechanism of CoZn-Te/NC, facilitated by bulk structural reconstruction of the nitrogen-doped carbon matrix and the robust heterostructure, effectively mitigates volume expansion and particle aggregation during cycling, contributing to its superior cycling stability and capacity retention. 3.1.3 Potassium ion battery (1) Zn-Co-Te In addition, Zhang et al. [103] adopted Zn/Co-ZIF-87 covered with a polydopamine (PDA) layer (Zn/Co-ZIF-87@PDA) as the precursor and then added tellurium powder for heat treatment to obtain the ZnTe/CoTe2 nitrogen-doped carbon heterostructure (ZnTe/CoTe2@NC) (as shown in Fig. 9 a). When the current density was increased from 0.1 to 20.0 A g−1, at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 A g−1, the reversible capacities of ZnTe/CoTe2@NC were 498.7, 430.8, 352.1, 279.9, 233.3, and 190.2 mAh g−1 respectively. (2) Sb-Bi-Te As shown in Fig. 10 (a), Cui et al. [104] synthesized SbBiTe3/graphite anodes using a simple and scalable ball-milling strategy. Metal chalcogenides (MCs), M2A3 (M = Sb, Bi; A = S, Se, Te), undergo conversion reactions with K-ions to make M particles be embedded in the K2A matrix. These M particles further alloy with K2A to form K x M particles as the final product. The phase transition and conversion reaction mechanism, involving the transformation of M2A3 into K2A and K x M, ensures efficient potassium storage and release, with this bulk structural reconstruction process contributing to the high capacity and stability of the anode. To further explain the relevant mechanism, the electronic localization function (ELF) of the K2A crystal containing a single K vacancy was calculated, as shown in Fig. 10(b). Since the initial insertion of K-ions into the M2A3 intermediate layer may be influenced by the choice of M, the lowest diffusion barrier for SbBiTe3 was calculated to be 0.107 eV, as shown in Fig. 10(c and d). The results suggest that the slight differences in the diffusion barriers of K-ions may have minimal impact on the overall potassium insertion dynamics. Fig. 10(e) summarizes the main properties of Sb and Bi anodes in potassium-ion batteries (KIBs), where the full name “potassium-ion batteries” is provided when the abbreviation is first introduced. Selecting the SbBi alloy anode ensures both high K storage capacity and good cycling stability. As shown in Fig. 10(f), the particles display the (110) and (015) crystal planes of SbBiTe3. By measuring and comparing the electrochemical performances of three different M2Te3 compounds made of the same chalcogen element (Te), it was found that the MC containing Sb exhibited a high theoretical K storage capacity, as shown in Fig. 10(g). The Coulombic efficiency fluctuates slightly, confirming that the bimetallic alloy demonstrates better cycling stability than the single-element compound, due to the synergistic effect, which further enhances the cycling stability of the SbBiTe3 electrode. As shown in Fig. 10(h), compared with the published literature, as the current density and number of cycles increase, the performance differences between different M2Te3 compounds gradually narrow. The capacities of these M2Te3 compounds were measured, and after 1000 cycles, the Coulombic efficiency remained continuously above 99%, with the specific capacity reaching 202 mAh g−1, indicating that SbBiTe3 has the potential to be a practical and high-performance anode for KIBs. Table 4 summarizes the performance of various bimetallic tellurides as water-splitting catalysts, showcasing the exceptional electrocatalytic properties of bimetallic tellurides. 4 Summary and outlook This review comprehensively explores the pivotal role of bimetallic tellurides in energy storage and conversion, along with their research progress. Through an in-depth analysis of material design, synthesis strategies, and performance optimization mechanisms, the unique advantages of bimetallic tellurides in supercapacitors, alkali metal-ion batteries, and electrocatalytic applications are revealed. The various synthesis strategies of bimetallic tellurides were summarized systematically, including hydrothermal, carburization, tellurization, chemical etching, and ball milling methods. Their outstanding electrochemical performance primarily stems from bimetallic synergistic effects, high conductivity, and abundant redox-active sites by adjusting the bimetallic ratio, nanostructural design and composite engineering, which collectively demonstrate significant potential in energy storage and conversion technologies. In alkali metal-ion batteries, bimetallic tellurides significantly enhance ion storage capacity and rate performance through pseudocapacitive contribution mechanisms and porous structure confinement effects. Additionally, electronic structure modulation mechanisms and synthesis-path-dependent crystalline phase control mechanisms provide theoretical support for achieving high energy density and long cycle life. In the field of supercapacitors, bimetallic tellurides markedly improve charge transfer efficiency via conductivity enhancement mechanisms, while ion transport and diffusion mechanisms optimize electrolyte penetration and ion migration kinetics. Furthermore, achieved through carbon matrix encapsulation and nanostructure design, effectively mitigate volume expansion during cycling, thereby ensuring long-term stability. In electrocatalysis, bimetallic tellurides significantly boost the catalytic activity of HER and OER through active site optimization and dynamic surface reconstruction, while heterointerface charge redistribution further enhance electron transport pathways and reaction kinetics. Despite their remarkable performance in energy-related applications, the practical implementation of bimetallic tellurides faces several challenges. For instance, hydrothermal and tellurization processes are often complex, costly, and difficult to scale up. Additionally, the scarcity and high cost of tellurium pose significant barriers to widespread adoption. Although their excellent electrochemical performance has been verified under experimental conditions, how to effectively improve electron and ion migration efficiency during high power density and fast charge-discharge processes, and avoid excessive polarization and degradation of the materials under high current density, is an urgent issue that needs to be addressed. In respect of structural tuning and metal ratio adjustment, how to effectively control the microstructure and metal composition of these materials in practical applications for preventing performance degradation during long-term operation. Moreover, the long-term stability and electrolyte compatibility of these materials require further improvement. Future research should focus on developing more efficient and cost-effective synthesis strategies, exploring multi-mechanism synergistic effects to further enhance material performance, and optimizing electrolyte systems to improve practical applicability. For example, exploring novel green solvents, mild reaction conditions, and one-step synthesis techniques could enable the industrial-scale production of bimetallic tellurides and their composite structures more easily. In addition, further research into the relationship between the structure and properties of bimetallic tellurides is essential. By precisely controlling factors such as the bimetallic ratio, crystal structure, microstructure, and composite configurations with other materials to enhance electrochemical performance. Simultaneously, integrating theoretical calculations with in situ characterization techniques to uncover the structural evolution and performance degradation mechanisms under dynamic operating conditions will provide critical guidance for the rational design of high-performance bimetallic tellurides. Furthermore, the future design of bimetallic tellurides electrodes can be regulated through various strategies, including heterostructure engineering, defect engineering, morphology engineering, and composite engineering. By combining different materials to form unique interface structures, not only is the electrical conductivity improved, but catalytic activity and stability are also enhanced. Introducing appropriate defects, such as vacancies and dopant atoms, further improving catalytic efficiency by adjust the electronic structure of the material, thereby enhancing the overall performance of the electrode. Additionally, morphology optimizing can effectively increase the surface area, improve the pore structure, result in fast ion migration rate. Composite engineering involves combining two or more materials to form composite materials, leveraging the advantages of each material while overcoming the limitations of individual components. In summary, bimetallic tellurides exhibit unique electronic properties and multi-mechanism synergistic effects, offering new opportunities for advancing next-generation energy storage and conversion technologies. By addressing current technical bottlenecks and fully leveraging their potential, bimetallic tellurides are poised to play a crucial role in driving energy technology innovation and achieving sustainable development goals. Ziyi Cheng is currently pursuing a Master’s degree at the School of Metallurgical Engineering, Anhui University of Technology, China. Her research focuses on energy conversion and storage technology. Lixin Qian is an Associate Professor at the School of Metallurgical Engineering, Anhui University of Technology, China. In 2021, he earned his Ph.D. in Metallurgical Engineering through a joint doctoral program between Anhui University of Technology and Western University, Canada (supervised by Academician Charles). His primary research focuses on catalytic abatement technologies for industrial flue gas pollutants. He has co-authored over 50 research papers and filed more than 20 patents. Wei Wang is a professor in School of Metallurgical and Ecological Engineering at the University of Science and Technology Beijing (USTB). He received his Ph.D. degree in State Key Laboratory of Advanced Metallurgy in 2016 from USTB and studied at University of Cambridge as a joint Ph.D. student. Before joining USTB in 2021, he was a postdoctoral researcher at Peking University and Harvard University and worked as a professor at Beihang University (BUAA). His research focuses on energy conversion and storage technology. He has co-authored over 200 research papers and filed more than 20 patents. Jianhua Chu is a professor in School of Metallurgical Engineering, Anhui University of Technology, China. He received his Ph.D. degree in State Key Laboratory of Advanced Metallurgy in 2022 from University of Science and Technology Beijing. His research focuses on energy conversion and storage technology. He has co-authored over 40 research papers and filed more than 10 patents.

coredata.dc:description: The rapid growth in global energy demand has necessitated the development of efficient energy storage and conversion devices, with the aim of enhancing grid stability, promoting the adoption of electric vehicles, and powering portable electronics. However, the performance of these devices is constrained by the limitations of traditional electrode materials and catalysts. Bimetallic tellurides have emerged as a promising solution due to their exceptional synergistic effects, high electronic conductivity, abundant redox-active sites, and outstanding electrochemical stability. Nevertheless, achieving cost-effective synthesis and stable applications remains a significant challenge. Hence, the most recent advances of bimetallic tellurides electrodes from synthesis to application are systematically reviewed. Several synthetic strategies for exquisite bimetallic tellurides nanostructures, including tellurization, ball-milling, solvo/hydrothermal, electrodeposition, wet chemical, and template method, are discussed. Moreover, the applications of bimetallic tellurides are extensively summarized in energy storage and conversion devices, which include alkali metal-ion batteries (Li-ion, Na-ion, and K-ion), supercapacitor, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Besides, the challenges and potential solutions of bimetallic telluride for energy applications are also suggested. This work provides fundamental insight and guidelines for the future design of bimetallic tellurides in energy storage and conversion technologies.
